awd_titl_txt: TWC:  Small:  Privacy Preserving Cooperation among Microgrids for Efficient Load Management on the Grid
awd_abstract_narration:
Smart grid integrates sensors and communication infrastructure into the existing power grid to enable operational intelligence. The concept of microgrid is emerging in conjunction with the smart grid wherein small segments of the grid can be isolated into self-sufficient islands to feed their own demand load with their local energy, e.g., wind, solar. To date, microgrids begin to develop cooperative models for further improving the performance of global and local load management, such as global/local load balancing, energy exchange, and power transmission network topology design/upgrade with the integration of microgrids. However, all the cooperation among microgrids requests them to explicitly share their local sensitive grid operational information for global performance optimization, and thus compromises the privacy of microgrids. Then, microgrids' privacy concerns would impede the development and implementation of the cooperative models such that significant benefits via microgrids' cooperation on the power grid may not be available. This project tackles the privacy concerns in such cooperation, and enables microgrids to efficiently manage their local loads as well as facilitate the main grid to manipulate the global load with limited disclosure.

This project proposes a suite of novel privacy preserving cooperative models/techniques for distributed microgrids to efficiently advance load management on the power grid. Provable privacy/security is ensured in the end-to-end process of cooperation, including privately analyzing data collected from different microgrids and privately implementing the schemes/solutions derived from the cooperative models, by composing cryptographic primitives with the secure multiparty computation (SMC) theory and/or imposing defined rigorous privacy notions. Ensuring privacy protection with rigorous standards will allow data to be collected and used in ways that were prohibitive earlier due to the privacy concerns, and then improve both operational efficiency and user acceptance. Load management via privacy preserving cooperation further optimally allocates distributed energy and minimizes the transmission and storage costs in a more secure, reliable and efficient smart grid infrastructure. This project also integrates research and education by exciting undergraduates to join the Science, Technology, Engineering and Math (STEM) research.

por.por_cntn:
Microgrids with local energy (generated by solar panels and wind turbines) can cooperate with each other to improve the performance of load management on the power grid. Such cooperation includes a series of energy exchanging activities among the microgrids, such as load balancing, energy sharing, energy trading, and energy auction. However, these applications request local sensitive grid operational information from all the microgrids (e.g., time-series power consumption, power generation, and power quality data) and may result in high privacy and security risks. In this project, we have addressed the problem of efficiently deriving the optimal cooperation decisions among distributed microgrids over their local sensitive data without compromising their privacy and security.

Specifically, we have proposed a set of cryptographic solutions to privately execute the end-to-end cooperation for the microgrids and the main grid over their sensitive data in real time. First, we have developed efficient techniques for energy sharing based on distributed linear optimization (thus microgrids can privately share their excessive local energy). Second, we have developed efficient cryptographic protocols for privately balancing the global and local demand and supply by privately solving a nonlinear programming problem with a new private approximation algorithm. Third, we have developed efficient cryptographic protocols and incentive compatible mechanisms for microgrids to privately trade their local energy with proportional allocation. Fourth, we have developed efficient systems to privately execute double auction for trading energy based on secure multiparty computation (MPC) and trusted execution environment (TEE), respectively. Finally, we have also designed a hybrid system by integrating TEE and Blockchain to securely execute the double auction. We have proven the security of the cryptographic protocols in this project under the theory of secure multiparty computation. We have also implemented the system prototypes (PAIRING, PEM, PANDA and Hybridized System) for all the above cryptographic protocols, which can be scaled to perform secure computation among more than 300 parties in real time.   

From the perspective of intellectual merit, this project has advanced the state-of-the-art of privacy preserving distributed data analysis in the domain of the smart grid and cyber-physical systems. It delivers several new efficient and privacy preserving solutions to different variants of distributed optimization problems jointly solved by a large number of distributed agents in real time. We have addressed many fundamental challenges underlying secure computation and privacy preserving data analysis, such as (1) co-designing the optimization algorithm and cryptographic protocol for improving the efficiency, (2) co-designing the cryptographic protocol and system for improving the efficiency, (3) composing the cryptographic primitives for real-time protocols, and (4) integrating incentive compatible mechanisms and cryptographic protocols. Furthermore, the results of this project have generated significant broader impacts by improving the operational efficiency and user acceptance for collaborative data analysis in the smart grid infrastructure. The delivered techniques can reduce the costs for energy transmission and storage with better real-time resource allocation on the power grid as more microgrids are incentivized into the cooperation without privacy concerns. This project has also trained both graduate and undergraduate students on cyber-physical systems security and privacy, as well as greatly supported the cybersecurity curriculum development.
